user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following get_rq_dauth_algo code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 8.13.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of get_rq_dauth_algo.
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3
get_rq_dauth_algo (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const algo_param)
{
  if (NULL == algo_param->value.str)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5; /* Assume MD5 by default */

  if (algo_param->quoted)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))

      /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

    /* No known algorithm has been detected */
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
  }
  /* The algorithm value is not quoted */
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

  /* No known algorithm has been detected */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The macro/function MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n is supplied with two character-pointer arguments that are not const-qualified: (1) algo_param->value.str (the struct member is probably declared as char *str) and (2) the concatenated token _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN which produces a string literal. If the implementation of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n (or the macros that expand to it) declares these parameters as plain char * (or otherwise non-const char *), then a pointer to non-const char is used where a pointer to const char should be used. Passing a string literal (an immutable object) to a non-const char * parameter and/or having struct members of pointer type that are not const violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. For compliance, the function/macro parameters and the member type should be const char * (and the struct member should be declared to point to const-qualified characters).
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_rq_dauth_algo:
struct MHD_RqDAuthParam
{
  /**
   * The string with length, NOT zero-terminated
   */
  struct _MHD_str_w_len value;
  /**
   * True if string must be "unquoted" before processing.
   * This member is false if the string is used in DQUOTE marks, but no
   * backslash-escape is used in the string.
   */
  bool quoted;
}
...
#define MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n(q, l, u) MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n(q,l,u,MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(u))
...
#define MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_(a, s, l) ((MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(a)==(l))&&MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_(a,s,l))
...
#define _MHD_SESS_TOKEN "-sess"
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report cannot be confirmed from the code shown. MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13 requires pointer types to be const-qualified when possible — this is a requirement on declarations. The supplied get_rq_dauth_algo uses algo_param as a const pointer to the struct, but that alone does not show whether the nested member value.str or the string-comparison APIs are declared with const-qualified pointer types. The agent’s claim hinges on two declarations that are not provided here: (1) the type of _MHD_str_w_len.value.str (char * vs const char *), and (2) the prototype(s) of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n / MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (whether their parameters are char * or const char *). If those APIs or the struct member are declared as plain char * (non-const), then the agent’s assertion is correct (MISRA R8.13 would be violated and the parameters/fields should be const char *). If they are already declared as const char *, there is no violation. Note also that concatenated token macros yield string literals (of array type), which should be treated as const char * for MISRA purposes. To settle this definitively inspect the declarations of _MHD_str_w_len (the type of value.str) and the prototypes of the MHD_str_* functions/macros. Recommended fix (if a violation is found): change the member and function parameters to const char * (or otherwise const-qualify pointers where mutation is not required).
